node.statement: PART (c) â€” CHAIN RULE IDENTITY. From node 1.6.5, after establishing omega_1_prime(nu_k) = 1, the Laurent expansion simplifies to: nG_p(omega_1(z)) = 1/(z - nu_k) + [H_p(lambda_{sigma(k)}) - omega_1_double_prime(nu_k)/2] + O(z - nu_k). Matching the constant term (coefficient of (z-nu_k)^0) with nG_r(z) = 1/(z - nu_k) + H_r(nu_k) + O(z - nu_k) gives: H_r(nu_k) = H_p(lambda_{sigma(k)}) - omega_1_double_prime(nu_k)/2. Defining alpha_k := omega_1_double_prime(nu_k)/2, this reads H_r(nu_k) = H_p(lambda_{sigma(k)}) - alpha_k. By identical computation with omega_2 and G_q, defining beta_k := omega_2_double_prime(nu_k)/2: H_r(nu_k) = H_q(mu_{tau(k)}) - beta_k. This completes part (c) and the entire proof of the Chain Rule for Discrete Hilbert Transform. QED.
